node.title: In the US, a boss sacked 900 staff over video call — but could it happen here?
node.description: A US mortgage company sacked hundreds of employees over video call just before Christmas, but experts say there are protections against that behaviour in Australia.
node.content:
["You're working in\u00a0your home office when you get a video conference invite from your company's chief executive. You jump on with 900 colleagues, only to learn\u00a0you don't have a job anymore.", "Not tomorrow, not next week \u2014\u00a0as of this call, you're unemployed.", "That's what 9 per cent of the workforce at US mortgage company Better.com experienced in a call with chief executive Vishal Garg last week.", "Video of the workers' summary dismissal\u00a0has gone viral on TikTok and YouTube, but experts say it could not have happened in Australia.\u00a0", "The call\u00a0opens with Mr Garg telling the\u00a0digital gathering\u00a0he has \"not great news\" to share.\u00a0", "\"This isn't news that you're going to want to hear but ultimately, it was my decision, and I wanted you to hear it from me,\" he says.", "", "
Vishal Garg said hundreds of workers needed to go, \"effective immediately\".(Supplied: Better.com)
", "He outlines how he cried last time he decided to sack staff\u00a0but \"hopes to be stronger\" this time before breaking the bad news.", "Mr Garg gives market conditions, efficiency, staff performance and productivity as reasons for his decision, going on to outline the severance benefits afforded to each employee.", "Better.com is a mortgage company that describes itself as \"using technology to make [mortgage services] faster and more efficient, and humans to help make it friendly and enjoyable\".", "It\u00a0announced\u00a0plans to go public earlier this year and gave a post-deal valuation at the time of $US7.7 billion ($10.9 billion).", "
Australian laws better protect workers, academic says
", "The loss of your job is a particularly\u00a0scary situation to contemplate just weeks before Christmas, but employment law expert Sean Cooney, a professor at Melbourne Law School, said workers in Australia were protected in ways those employed by US companies are not.", "\"This is something which is much more possible in the United States than in many other jurisdictions,\" he said.", "There are some exceptions to that \u2014\u00a0discrimination, for example \u2014 but Professor Cooney said\u00a0employment law was much more favourable to bosses in the US.", "\"If you ever watch some of those old American\u00a0TV shows \u2026 where an employer says, 'You're sacked' straight away \u2026\u00a0you sort of take a step back and think, 'Hang on, you can't do that' \u2014\u00a0\u00a0but you can in the US,\" he said.", "\"Here, you can complain to the Fair Work Commission and so forth if you had an extreme situation like the one in the video.\"", "", "
There are greater protections against summary dismissal in Australia, compared to the US.(Unsplash: Israel Andrade)
", "Professor Cooney said the unfair dismissal system, coupled with a more robust redundancy and consultation processes, protected\u00a0workers in Australia better than those dismissed from Better.com.", "He also said the US workforce was far less unionised than Australia's, something Australian Council of Trade Unions secretary Sally McManus said could make a difference for workers.", "\u201cEmployers should always treat working people with respect, but this also illustrates the need for strong rights for working people to stand together and demand fair and equitable treatment,\" she said.", "\u201cUnfortunately these rights have been eroded in America and are being increasingly stripped away here.\"", "Professor Cooney said it was unlikely US employment\u00a0laws would fall into line\u00a0with the rest of the developed world, saying they were \"entrenched\".", "\"It goes along with not having paid annual leave as a national standard, not having maternity leave, really if you compare to Australia or Canada, New Zealand,\u00a0the European Union and many countries in Asia, the US has much weaker rights and entitlements for workers,\" he said."]
